When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they should not view conditions as either permanent or impermanent, nor should they view equal and immediate conditions, dominant conditions, or contributory conditions as either permanent or impermanent;
they should not view conditions as either blissful or suffering, nor should they view equal and immediate conditions, dominant conditions, or contributory conditions as either blissful or suffering;

they should not view ignorance as either blissful or suffering, nor should they view volitional formations up to aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as either blissful or suffering;

they should not view ignorance as either empty or not empty, nor should they view volitional formations up to aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as either empty or not empty;

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they should not view internal emptiness as either permanent or impermanent, and they should not view external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, empty emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, conditioned emptiness, unconditioned emptiness, absolute emptiness, limitless emptiness, dispersed emptiness, unchanging emptiness, inherent emptiness, specific emptiness, common emptiness, all dharmas emptiness, emptiness of non-attainment, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, or emptiness of the nature of self-nature as either permanent or impermanent;ğŸ”½they should not view internal emptiness as either blissful or suffering, and they should not view external emptiness up to the emptiness of the nature of self-nature as either blissful or suffering;

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they should not view the four establishments of mindfulness as permanent or impermanent, and they should not view the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path as permanent or impermanent;

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they should not view the eight liberations as either permanent or impermanent, nor should they view the eight superior realms, nine sequential attainments, or ten universal bases as either permanent or impermanent;
